trans-unit.source:
The module offers the creation of a page tree either with TCA demo records or content elements.
In addition, the most well-known backend components that come with the TYPO3 CMS are presented.
Browse and explore the TYPO3 backend component library including buttons, forms, cards, tables, and other UI elements.
Create and manage example page trees with TCA demo records or content elements for testing and demonstration purposes.
Explore design tokens, color schemes, typography, shadows, and other styling elements used in the TYPO3 backend.
Collapsible content sections that expand and collapse to show or hide information.
Display images representing backend users with optional status indicators.
Small labels for displaying status, counts, or categorization information.
Navigation trail showing the current location in the backend hierarchy, including modules and records.
Interactive elements for triggering actions with various styles, sizes, and states.
Flexible containers for grouping related content, displayed individually or in groups.
Form controls for selecting one or more options, including toggles and switches.
Input fields with dropdown suggestions for selecting or entering values.
A two-panel container with a resizable navigation area and a flexible content area.
Predefined color values and design tokens used throughout the TYPO3 backend interface.
Stateful color variants for interactive elements including accent colors and semantic states.
Browse all available UI components in the TYPO3 backend component library.
Specialized components and utilities for development and debugging purposes.
Toggleable overlays for displaying lists, menus, and contextual actions.
Temporary notifications for displaying feedback about user actions and system events.
Complete form layouts combining various input fields and controls.
Complete library of icons available for use in the TYPO3 backend interface.
Highlighted containers for displaying important information and contextual help.
Text input fields with support for various types, states, and sizes.
Lists for displaying a series of content.
Create and manage example page trees with TCA demo records or content elements for testing purposes.
Dialog windows that appear on top of page content for focused interactions.
Navigation components including tabs, pills, and flat navigation styles.
Temporary messages for informing users about events with optional action buttons.
Controls for navigating through multi-page content and data sets.
Collapsible content containers for organizing information into sections.
Visual indicators showing completion status of tasks and processes.
Segmented progress displays for multi-step processes like wizards.
Form controls for selecting a single option from multiple choices.
Dropdown menus for choosing one or more options from a list.
Shadow effects and elevation styles used to create depth in the interface.
Browse all available design styles including colors, typography, and visual tokens.
Background surfaces and container styles that define the visual hierarchy.
Organized content sections with clickable headers for switching between views.
Structured layouts for displaying tabular data with optional action icons.
Multi-line text input fields for entering longer content.
Hierarchical tree structures for displaying nested data and navigation.
Font styles, sizes, weights, and text formatting used throughout the backend.
An error occured while processing the page tree
Delete page tree and all related records
A page tree with TCA demo records was created.
A page tree with TCA demo records exists already. Please delete that first.
The page tree and all related records were deleted.
Create page tree with site sets
Delete page tree and all related records
A page tree with content elements was created.
A page tree with content elements exists already. Please delete that first.
The page tree and all related records were deleted.

An avatar displays an image that represents a backend user and can provide additional information such as their status.
Avatars can be displayed with an own ViewHelper. If an avatar image is stored in the user settings, this will be used instead of the standard image.
Display the backend user's avatar image or a static fallback image for users without avatar images.
If set, the backend user type (normal user or admin user) and its status (disabled or not) will be displayed next to the avatar.
Small labels for displaying status, counts, or categorization information in a compact format.
Navigation trail showing the current location in the backend hierarchy, including modules and pages.
Interactive elements for triggering actions, available in various colors, sizes, and states.
Cards can be displayed individually or in groups.

If you have multiple cards and each have a link or button, they may not align properly depending on the length of the previously placed headings or description text. To ensure they align regardless of previous content, place the link or button inside div.card-footer and not inside div.card-body. This way the links will always be aligned at the bottom of the card.

It is possible to color cards. However, this option is rarely used - so please use this option sparingly. All available options are listed below. If needed assign one of the following classes to the div.card.
If you want to display the card in its default state, it is not necessary to add .card-default to the div.card - just omit the extra class.
This is an example of a single card with its possible content. Unless further defined via CSS, a single card takes on the full width of the place it has been put into.
In the extension manager it is possible to get pre-configured distributions. For this view, the cards have been enhanced with an image and some badges.

It is also possible to display forms and form fields in cards. This is done, for example, in the "Upload Extension" section of the "Extensions" module, in the "Feature Toggles" overlay in the "Settings" module and in the "Raw search" submodule of the "Database" module.
To display multiple cards, group them by wrapping them with div.card-container.
On top of the element information overlay, rows are included within the card component.
To give the card the desired size, assign one of the following classes to the div.card. If only a single card is used, it must be wrapped with div.card-container as with multiple cards.
Form controls for selecting one or more options, including standard checkboxes, toggles, and switches.
Input fields with dropdown suggestions for selecting or entering values, combining text input with selection capabilities.
Toggleable overlays for displaying lists, menus, and contextual actions in a compact dropdown format.
Specialized components and utilities designed for development, debugging, and testing purposes.
Temporary notifications for displaying feedback about user actions and system events in various severity levels.
The color is decided by setting the corresponding TYPO3\CMS\Core\Type\ContextualFeedbackSeverity. The following options are available:
Complete form layouts combining various input fields, controls, and validation patterns.
Form with all fields and labels
Form with all fields and labels (right-to-left direction)
This is a fluid based widget for the backend that can be inserted as view helper.
It is also possible to use a custom icon. Just pass the icon identifier as iconName to the view helper. The identifier must be registered in your TYPO3 installation.
Text input fields supporting various types, states, and sizes for single-line data entry.
Lists for displaying a series of content.
Add .list-group-flush to remove the surrounding border and display the list group borderless in a parent container (e.g., cards)
Modals on buttons can be triggered using the t3js-modal-trigger class. There are various data attributes to customize text and behavior. Not all of them are shown here.
Custom title and content within the modal
Navigation components including tabs, pills, and flat navigation styles for organizing content.
Temporary messages for informing users about events with optional action buttons and different severity levels. Error notifications persist until dismissed.
Notification can be enriched with action buttons to trigger two kinds of actions: immediate action and deferred actions.

Immediate actions are executed directly when the action button is triggered. The notification will dismiss immediately. This action type is suitable for action that don't need any processing time, e.g. calling a backend module.

Deferred actions are suitable for actions that need a period of time until they finish, e.g. AJAX calls. The notifications will close as soon the action has ended successfully. When invoked, the button will show a spinner icon to indicate some activity.
All notifications disappear after 5 seconds by default, except for the error message, which will remain stuck unless reconfigured.
Controls for navigating through multi-page content and data sets with page numbers and navigation arrows.
Collapsible content containers for organizing information into expandable and collapsible sections.

Progress bars represent a specific state that can be displayed in a percental fashion, e.g. amount of uploaded files, executed Upgrade Wizards or disk space usage.
If the exact amount of data being loaded is not known, progress bars may be rendered in an indeterminate state.
If applicable, use clear wording that describes the progress bar.
Optionally, a label can be displayed below the progress bar.
By default, an indefinite progress is displayed.

Progress trackers are a segmented variant of progress bars, dividing the progress bar into equal chunks.
The primary usage is in wizard components.
Form controls for selecting a single exclusive option from multiple mutually exclusive choices.

A two-panel container with a resizable navigation area and a flexible content area. The navigation panel is optional, resizable, and can be collapsed to the left. The content panel is required and fills the remaining space.

The content navigation uses named slots: navigation and content. The content slot is required. The navigation panel can be collapsed by dragging below half of its minimum width. When collapsed, an expand button with the panel title is displayed.
The navigation panel can be expanded or collapsed programmatically using expand(), collapse(), and isCollapsed() methods.

The <typo3-backend-content-navigation-toggle> component provides a button to expand or collapse the navigation. Place it anywhere within the content-navigation component. Use action="collapse" for a collapse button (visible when expanded) or action="expand" for an expand button (visible when collapsed). The component automatically shows/hides based on the navigation state and reads labels from the parent content-navigation's navigation-label-collapse and navigation-label-expand attributes.

The navigation panel can be hidden by adding the hidden attribute to the slotted element. Use the component's showNavigation(), hideNavigation(), and isNavigationHidden() methods for programmatic control.
The navigation width is automatically persisted to localStorage using the container's identifier attribute. Resize the panel below, then reload the page to see the width restored.
The container automatically adapts to right-to-left layouts. The navigation panel appears on the right and drag directions are mirrored.

When the container becomes too narrow (below 750px), the navigation automatically switches to flyout mode using CSS container queries. In flyout mode, the navigation overlays the content instead of sitting beside it, and resizing is disabled.
Dropdown menus for choosing one or more options from a predefined list of values.
Organized content sections with clickable headers for switching between different views and panels.
The last selected tab is stored in local browser storage.
Use tables to show tabular data. The action icons should always be in the last table row cell.
To color table rows, a class can be added to the tr element.
Multi-line text input fields for entering and editing longer content and formatted text.
Hierarchical tree structures for displaying and navigating nested data with expandable and collapsible nodes.

Collapsible trees are used to show the configuration in a more structured way. Lower levels can be opened and closed, while the entries are collapsed by default. If a user opens entries, this state is saved in the session. There are additional data attributes that can be added to div.treelist-collapse to configure the collapse state.
File trees are initialized via TypeScript like the page trees.
Initialization of a page tree is done via TypeScript as in the code example below.
Surfaces used in the TYPO3 Backend, for internal usage only.

Stateful color variants used for interactive elements in the TYPO3 Backend, for internal usage only. These include accent colors (primary, secondary) and semantic state colors (info, success, warning, danger, notice) with their respective default, hover, focus, and disabled variants.
Icons can be used in backend modules. TYPO3 automatically sends the corresponding HTML output code.
Shadows used in the TYPO3 Backend, for internal usage only.
Surfaces used in the TYPO3 Backend, for internal usage only.
Font styles, sizes, weights, and text formatting guidelines used throughout the TYPO3 backend.

Headline "H1" is the main headline within each backend module. Only added once to every backend page.
Headline "H2" is the headline for every section in backend modules. Place above each section and use several times.
Headline "H3" can be used to split section content into logical units. Place in between paragraphs within section.
Headline "H4" might be used to split off meta / footer information.

By default, ordered and unordered lists are formatted with bullets and decimals. By adding class="list-unstyled" to the ol or ul tag, it is possible to structure content in list form without the typical list styling.
Footer information, small notices can be wrapped in small text tag.
